turns.content: How did A Plain Account of Christian Perfection differ from Wesley's other works?

A Plain Account of Christian Perfection differed from Wesley's other works in that it was a simple and straightforward explanation of the concept of Christian perfection, without the use of technical or theological language. Wesley wrote this book for the average person, to explain the process of sanctification and how to attain it. 

Unlike other works that focused on the doctrine and theology of Christian perfection, A Plain Account presented the practical steps one could take to achieve perfection. The book emphasizes the importance of repentance, faith in Jesus Christ, and the work of the Holy Spirit in the life of a believer. Wesley also included personal anecdotes and examples to help readers understand the concept better. 

Overall, A Plain Account was more accessible and relatable to the average person than some of Wesley's other works. It was a guide towards a practical and achievable goal rather than just an intellectual exercise.

Sounds like A Plain Account of Christian Perfection would have been a better introduction to Wesley's ideas than some of his harder-to-understand works. Do you happen to know if it was well-received among his followers at the time?

Yes, A Plain Account of Christian Perfection was very well-received among Wesley's followers at the time. It became one of his most popular and influential works, and many Methodists found it to be a helpful guide for their spiritual journey. The book was widely circulated within the Methodist movement and beyond, and it continues to be studied and appreciated by Christians of many denominations today. 

Wesley himself believed that the book had the power to transform lives and wrote in the preface, "I hope this little book may be a means, under God, of promoting justifying, sanctifying faith among those who are seeking to know Jesus Christ, and him crucified."
Interesting, it seems like A Plain Account of Christian Perfection was more like Wesley's "idiot's guide" to his beliefs. I wonder if he had any other books that were more for advanced readers?

Yes, Wesley did have other works that were more nuanced and aimed at more advanced readers. Some of Wesley's other works that are specifically focused on theology and doctrine include "The Doctrine of Original Sin According to Scripture, Reason, and Experience," and "The Doctrine of Justification By Faith." These works are more complex and require a deeper understanding of theological concepts.

However, it is worth noting that Wesley's focus was always on making his ideas accessible to as many people as possible. He believed that anyone could understand and benefit from his teachings, regardless of their level of education or background. This is evidenced by the fact that he often preached in open-air settings and used simple language that the common people could understand. 

Overall, Wesley's approach was to offer different works for different readers, depending on their level of understanding and interest in the subject matter. However, he always prioritized accessibility and the goal of reaching as many people as possible with his message.
